Study: Isothermal evaporation rate of deposited liquid aerosols and the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus survival
Conclusion: It was shown that the main experimental results on the dynamics of coronavirus survival on various surfaces correlate well with the rate of isothermal evaporation of liquid samples with viruses on substrates which do not absorb moisture. The evaporation rate depends on the thermal conductivity and thickness of the substrate, as well as the relative humidity of the surrounding air.

Study: Aerosol and surface stability of HCoV-19 (SARS-CoV-2) compared to SARS-CoV-1
Method: End-point titration on Vero E6 cells
Conclusion: HCoV-19 persists for 3 hrs in aerosols.

Study: Aerosol and surface stability of HCoV-19 (SARS-CoV-2) compared to SARS-CoV-1
Method: End-point titration on Vero E6 cells
Conclusion: HCoV-19 persists for 72 hrs on plastic.

Study: Aerosol and surface stability of HCoV-19 (SARS-CoV-2) compared to SARS-CoV-1
Method: End-point titration on Vero E6 cells
Conclusion: HCoV-19 persists for 72 hrs onstainless steel.

Study: Aerosol and surface stability of HCoV-19 (SARS-CoV-2) compared to SARS-CoV-1
Method: End-point titration on Vero E6 cells
TCID50: No viable virus could be measured after 4 hours on copper
Conclusion: HCoV-19 persists for 4 hrs on copper.

Study: Aerosol and surface stability of HCoV-19 (SARS-CoV-2) compared to SARS-CoV-1
Method: End-point titration on Vero E6 cells
TCID50: No viable virus could be measured after 24 hours on cardboard
Conclusion: HCoV-19 persists for 24 hrs on cardboard.
